WOW.heroDescription: 38% Grocery Market Share • 202,000 Employees • A$69.1B Revenue
WOW.heroCompanyDescription: Woolworths Group (ASX: WOW) is Australia's largest supermarket operator, commanding 38% of the domestic grocery market through its Woolworths and Metro brands. The group also operates Big W discount department stores, Petstock pet retail, and a growing e-commerce platform reaching 16.2% online penetration.

skew.rationale: Evidence accumulating against the embedded turnaround narrative. Premium multiple with unproven recovery thesis.

verdict.text: The market is pricing a Bardwell turnaround at a premium multiple, but FY25 delivered a 19% NPAT decline. FY26 is "transitional"; the 1H results on 25 February are the single most diagnostic event for whether this is a trough or a new normal.

WOW.featuredRationale: Premium multiple pricing turnaround, but FY25 delivered 19% NPAT decline. 1H FY26 is the test.

XRO.heroDescription: Cloud Accounting • 4.6M Subscribers • NZ$2.10B Revenue • AI Sell-Off Target
XRO.heroCompanyDescription: Xero Limited (ASX: XRO) is a New Zealand-founded, ASX-listed cloud accounting platform serving 4.6 million subscribers globally. The stock has become ground zero for the AI disruption repricing of SaaS: down 57% from its A$194 high to A$78.50, with the ASX tech sector collapsing 9.4% in a single session triggered by AI capability demonstrations (Anthropic Claude specifically cited as catalyst). Analyst consensus remains unanimously Buy with an average target of A$191, representing 130% upside. Either the market is right and AI will structurally impair cloud accounting, or this is the widest dislocation between price and fundamentals in Xero's listed history.

skew.rationale: The sell-off has now reached 57% on zero evidence of actual churn, customer loss, or revenue deceleration. Every analyst rates Buy. AI disruption fears are legitimate as a long-term structural question, but the market is pricing terminal impairment of a business that just delivered 20% revenue growth, historic low churn, and Rule of 40 at 44.5%. At A$78.50, the risk-reward skews decisively upside: unless AI displaces accounting software faster than any technology transition in history.

verdict.text: Xero has become the defining test case for the AI-disrupts-SaaS thesis. The stock is down 57% from its highs: an acceleration from the 55% decline just weeks ago: after an ASX tech sector rout triggered by Anthropic's Claude AI demonstrations that the market interpreted as threatening to cloud accounting moats. But here are the facts: revenue grew 20%, ARPU grew 15%, churn is at historic lows, Rule of 40 is 44.5%, and all 15 covering analysts rate Buy with an average target of A$191 (130% upside). The Melio B2B payments acquisition is approaching breakeven 6-12 months ahead of schedule. The gap between what the business is doing and what the market is pricing has never been wider. This is either the opportunity of the cycle or the market correctly front-running a paradigm shift that hasn't yet appeared in any metric.

XRO.featuredRationale: AI disruption sell-off deepens to -57%. Anthropic Claude demo triggered ASX tech rout. Zero churn evidence. All 15 analysts Buy at avg A$191 (130% upside). Widest price-vs-fundamentals gap in Xero history.

The platform expansion strategy is working by every measurable metric. But the market is pricing none of it. The stock is down 57% from A$194 despite delivering four consecutive earnings beats. All 15 covering analysts rate Buy with an average target of A$191 (130% upside from A$78.50). The dislocation between price and fundamentals has never been wider in Xero's history.

B2B payments are becoming the wedge product for US SMB market penetration. The payments+accounting bundle creates a competitive proposition that QuickBooks cannot match on payments and PayPal cannot match on accounting. At current depressed valuations, the market is assigning near-zero value to Melio: any evidence of integration success represents pure upside optionality.

hypotheses.title: N3: AI Disruption Re-Prices SaaS
hypotheses.statusText: Dominant: Deepening. Anthropic Claude Cited as Catalyst
hypotheses.scoreMeta: ↑ Deepening; specific AI catalyst now identified
hypotheses.description: This thesis has intensified from theoretical to market-moving. The February 2026 sell-off was specifically triggered by Anthropic's Claude AI demonstrations, which the market interpreted as capable of automating core accounting workflows. The ASX IT Index fell 9.4% in a single session. Xero fell from ~A$95 to A$78.50, breaking through every prior support level. The 60% drawdown from A$194 is no longer a generic SaaS re-rating: it is the market pricing a specific, named AI threat to cloud accounting business models. The absence of churn is noted but considered a lagging indicator by the market. Price leads fundamentals; this is the market front-running a structural shift.
supporting: Market Price: Stock down 57% from A$194.21 to A$78.50 in 8 months. The most powerful evidence domain. A drawdown of this magnitude, accelerating, is not sentiment: it is repricing

Sector-Wide: ASX IT Index fell 9.4% in one session; broad SaaS de-rating accelerating globally as AI disruption reprices growth expectations
Media & Narrative: "AI disrupts accounting" is now the dominant framing; Xero named alongside other SaaS casualties in major financial press
contradicting: Financial Statements: Churn at historic lows; no sign of customer departure. This remains the strongest counter-evidence and is independently verifiable

Academic: Research shows AI augments accounting workflows; full automation requires regulatory compliance, judgment, and liability frameworks that don't exist
Xero's AI Response: Company planning AI monetisation for FY27; argues domain expertise, decades of data, payment rails, and 1,000+ app ecosystem create an AI moat, not vulnerability
Alternative Data: No visible churn signal in app downloads, web traffic, customer reviews, or NPS scores

hypotheses.scoreMeta: ↓ No competitive share loss in any market

This thesis has weakened further: no competitor is demonstrably taking share, Intuit's growth is in tax and mid-market (not SMB cloud), and MYOB remains stagnant under private ownership. The AI disruption thesis (N3) has absorbed this hypothesis's energy: if Xero is displaced, it will be by AI-native tools, not by existing competitors.

rows: Anthropic Claude demo; ASX IT Index -9.4%
identity.overview: New Zealand-headquartered cloud accounting platform serving 4.6 million subscribers globally. Stock down 57% in 8 months as AI disruption fears rip through the SaaS sector: Anthropic's Claude AI was specifically cited as a catalyst for the February 2026 tech rout that saw the ASX IT Index fall 9.4% in one session. Despite the sell-off, the business is executing: revenue +20%, ARPU +15%, Rule of 40 at 44.5%, churn at historic lows. Melio B2B payments acquisition (US$2.5B) approaching breakeven 6-12 months ahead of plan. Xero argues its moat lies in domain expertise, decades of accounting data, regulatory compliance, payment rails, and a 1,000+ app ecosystem that AI cannot replicate overnight.

WTC.heroCompanyDescription: WiseTech Global (ASX: WTC) is an Australian logistics technology company whose CargoWise platform is the dominant operating system for international freight forwarding, customs brokerage, and supply chain management. verdict.text: Governance crisis dominates despite strong product. Thirteen analysts rate Buy (avg target A$101.21, 105% upside), but targets predate the board mass departure.

CSL.heroDescription: Global Plasma Leader • 29,904 Employees • 1H FY26: US$8.3B Revenue
CSL.heroCompanyDescription: CSL Limited (ASX: CSL) is a global biotherapeutics company and the world's largest collector and manufacturer of human plasma-derived therapies. Operating through CSL Behring (plasma), CSL Seqirus (vaccines), and CSL Vifor (iron deficiency), the company serves patients in over 100 countries. Shares at 8-year lows following CEO departure, $1.1B impairments, and 81% reported NPAT drop in 1H FY26: though underlying NPATA only fell 7% and guidance was reaffirmed.

skew.rationale: 8-year low valuation at 13x forward P/E with underlying business intact. 1H was messy (81% reported NPAT drop, $1.1B impairments, CEO exit), but underlying NPATA only fell 7%, guidance reaffirmed, Behring margins expanding, and $550M cost savings on track. The market is pricing the worst-case transformation scenario while ignoring the franchise quality. Risk skew tilts upside at these levels.

verdict.text: 1H FY26 results are in and the picture is clear: this is a messy transition, not a broken franchise. Reported NPAT dropped 81% to US$401M on $1.1B of impairments (mRNA write-down, Venofer generics, plant closures), but underlying NPATA fell only 7% to US$1.9B. CEO McKenzie exited the day before results. The stock crashed 17% to 8-year lows at A$151. At 13x forward P/E, the market is pricing permanent impairment of the core plasma franchise: which the numbers do not support. Behring margins are expanding, Vifor grew 12%, and full-year guidance was reaffirmed. The execution risk is real, but the price dislocation now exceeds the fundamental risk.

Trading at 19.1x forward P/E, the market is not fully pricing the structural drivers from energy transition capital flows.

FMG.heroDescription: Iron Ore • 198 Mt Shipped (FY25) • US$7.9B EBITDA
FMG.heroCompanyDescription: Fortescue Ltd (ASX: FMG) is the world's fourth-largest iron ore producer, supplying approximately 10% of global seaborne iron ore. Founded by Andrew Forrest in 2003, Fortescue shipped a record 198.4 Mt in FY25 from its Pilbara operations at an industry-leading C1 cost of US$18.17/wmt. The company also operates Fortescue Energy, pursuing green hydrogen, green iron, and copper opportunities.

skew.rationale: Iron ore faces structural decline from China peak steel, Simandou adds 120 Mtpa of new supply by 2030, green energy writeoffs have destroyed capital, and the stock trades well above consensus broker targets. Forrest governance adds capital misallocation risk.

verdict.text: Fortescue's Metals division is a world-class mining operation: record 198.4 Mt shipped at US$18.17/wmt C1 cost, generating 56% EBITDA margins. But the investment case is overwhelmed by structural constraints. China has passed peak steel (2020), iron ore prices are forecast to decline to US$83-95/t by end-2026, Simandou will add 120 Mtpa of new supply, and the Energy division has written off US$150M+ on cancelled green hydrogen projects. Andrew Forrest's ~36% stake concentrates governance risk. The stock trades above consensus broker targets of A$18.58-19.86, making it one of the few ASX 50 stocks where the market is more bullish than analysts.

The embedded thesis is that iron ore earnings sustain the dividend floor while copper and potash deliver the growth.

hypotheses.title: N1: Copper Supercycle
hypotheses.description: Structural copper supply deficit emerges as electrification (EVs require 3-4x more copper than ICE vehicles), AI data centre build-out, grid infrastructure upgrades, and renewable energy installations drive demand growth of 3-5% annually. BHP's expanded copper portfolio (Escondida, Olympic Dam, OZ Minerals assets) positions it as one of the top 3 global copper producers. Copper grows from ~25% to 35-40% of group EBITDA by FY2028.
requires: Copper price sustains above US$4.00/lb (current ~US$4.20-4.50)
Escondida debottlenecking delivers incremental volume
Olympic Dam smelter upgrades complete without major delays
OZ Minerals integration delivers synergies and production ramp
Global electrification capex remains on structural uptrend
supporting: Supply-Demand: Copper supply gap forecast at 10+ Mt by 2035. New deposits increasingly rare, declining grades, 10+ year permitting timelines
Macro: EV adoption accelerating globally; AI data centres consuming thousands of tonnes per facility for wiring and cooling
Corporate: OZ Minerals integration on track. BHP building a South Australian copper province alongside Olympic Dam
M&A Signal: BHP's GBP39B Anglo American approach (2024) underscores strategic conviction in copper
contradicting: Cyclical: Copper can still fall 20-30% in a global recession, regardless of structural thesis
Substitution: Aluminium substitution in some applications could moderate demand growth
Execution: Olympic Dam smelter has a history of operational disruptions and cost overruns

hypotheses.title: N2: Iron Ore Cash Machine
hypotheses.description: Iron ore remains the dominant earnings driver. Pilbara operations produce ~280-290 Mtpa at industry-leading C1 costs of US$15-17/t. Iron ore prices remain supported at US$100-120/t by infrastructure spending, manufacturing demand, and emerging market urbanisation (India). Dividend policy (min 50% payout) plus buybacks generate total returns of 7-9% annually.

Discipline: Management maintains strong balance sheet (net debt target US$5-15B) and resists value-destructive M&A

Decarbonisation: Long-term shift to scrap-based electric arc furnaces reduces virgin iron ore demand

hypotheses.title: N3: China Property Drag
hypotheses.description: China's property sector remains in a prolonged downturn (Evergrande, Country Garden defaults). New housing starts have fallen significantly from peak. If China's steel production declines materially, iron ore prices could fall to US$80-90/t, compressing BHP's largest earnings segment by 30-40%. Infrastructure spending provides a partial offset but cannot fully compensate.
supporting: Property Data: China new housing starts down substantially from peak. Property investment declining
Steel Production: China crude steel production may have peaked; government targeting capacity reductions
Developer Defaults: Evergrande, Country Garden, and other developer restructurings signal structural demand decline
contradicting: Infrastructure: China infrastructure and manufacturing capex partially offsets property weakness
Policy: Chinese government stimulus measures supporting construction activity
India Offset: India's steel demand growth provides a partial substitute demand source
Cost Buffer: BHP's US$15-17/t cost position means profitability even at US$80/t iron ore

hypotheses.title: N4: Commodity Cycle Peak
hypotheses.description: We are near the top of a commodity supercycle. A global recession or demand shock causes simultaneous declines in iron ore, copper, and met coal prices. BHP's earnings are highly leveraged to commodity prices it does not control. A 2008-style downturn could see a 40-50% earnings decline. The Nickel West impairment (US$2.5B write-down) is a reminder that commodity thesis conviction can prove wrong.
supporting: Nickel Precedent: BHP wrote down US$2.5B on Nickel West after Indonesian supply overwhelmed the market
Cyclicality: Iron ore has traded between US$50-230/t over the past decade. Current ~US$110-120 is mid-range
Anglo American: Failed GBP39B bid raised questions about M&A discipline and management growth appetite
contradicting: Structural Demand: Electrification and infrastructure provide structural floor for copper
Cost Position: BHP's first-quartile costs across iron ore and copper provide recession resilience
Balance Sheet: Net debt at US$12B well within US$5-15B target; no liquidity stress
Diversification: Potash (Jansen) adds a countercyclical commodity to the portfolio from FY27

identity.overview: BHP Group (ASX: BHP) is the world's largest diversified miner. Iron ore from the Pilbara (~50-55% of EBITDA) provides the cash generation base. The strategic pivot toward copper is underway: the A$9.6B OZ Minerals acquisition (2023) added Prominent Hill and Carrapateena to Escondida and Olympic Dam, building one of the world's largest copper resource bases. Jansen potash (Saskatchewan, Canada) represents BHP's largest greenfield investment at ~US$5.7B, with first production expected late CY2026. Nickel West was placed on care and maintenance in 2024. The failed ~GBP39B approach for Anglo American (mid-2024) highlighted BHP's appetite for further copper consolidation.

The SaaS transition story remains intact but execution is under scrutiny. Founder Tony Walls's ~55% ownership creates alignment but also governance concentration risk.

RFG.heroDescription: Gloria Jean's • Donut King • Brumby's • Crust Pizza • Franchise Model
RFG.heroCompanyDescription: Retail Food Group (ASX: RFG) is one of Australia's largest multi-brand food franchise operators. Key brands include Gloria Jean's Coffees, Donut King, Brumby's Bakery, Crust Gourmet Pizza, and Pizza Capers. Asset-light franchise model earns royalties, wholesale supply margins, and licensing fees. Turnaround in progress after 2017-2020 franchise crisis. Network stabilised at ~1,000-1,200 outlets from peak of 2,400+.

skew.rationale: At 52-week low with persistent downtrend and no signs of basing. History of franchise scandals, ACCC scrutiny, and massive value destruction. Turnaround partially succeeded but market losing patience. Elevated debt, thin liquidity, and micro-cap status amplify risk.

verdict.text: Retail Food Group is a turnaround story running out of patience, trading at its 52-week low of A$1.07: down 58% from peak. The franchise crisis of 2017-2020 destroyed enormous value (share price collapsed from ~A$8 to near zero pre-consolidation). Under CEO Peter George, the company has stabilised operations, reduced debt, and returned to underlying profitability. But the persistent downtrend and micro-cap status signal the market remains deeply sceptical about sustainable growth.

CBA.heroDescription: Australia's Largest Bank • 53,000 Employees • 1H FY25: $5.1B Cash NPAT
CBA.heroCompanyDescription: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (ASX: CBA) is Australia's largest bank by market capitalisation and holds the #1 or #2 position across retail deposits, home lending, business banking, and digital payments. CBA serves approximately 17 million customers through a branch network, digital platforms (CommBank app with 8.7M+ monthly active users), and institutional banking. The stock trades at a persistent premium to major bank peers, reflecting franchise quality and digital leadership: but the premium has expanded to historically extreme levels at ~24x forward P/E.

skew.rationale: CBA trades at ~24x forward earnings, a 40%+ premium to NAB and ANZ, and well above its own 10-year average of ~16x. While franchise quality and digital leadership justify some premium, the current valuation leaves no margin for error. NIM compression is underway as rate cuts begin, mortgage competition is intensifying, and credit costs are likely to normalise from cyclical lows. Risk skew tilts to the downside at these elevated multiples.

verdict.text: 1H FY25 delivered cash NPAT of $5.13B, up 2% on pcp, with NIM of 1.99% (down 4bp). The franchise continues to perform: home lending grew 5.2%, business lending 8.7%, and the CommBank app now has 8.7M monthly active users. CET1 capital is strong at 12.2%. However, at ~24x forward P/E, CBA is priced for perfection in an environment where NIMs are compressing, mortgage competition is fierce, and the RBA is cutting rates. The quality is undeniable, but the price already reflects it and then some. The risk/reward is asymmetric to the downside at current levels.

CBA.featuredRationale: Highest-quality Australian bank franchise but priced at historically extreme multiples. The 40%+ P/E premium to peers leaves no room for NIM compression or credit normalisation. Quality is not in question: valuation is.

hypotheses.description: CBA's digital-first strategy, dominant market position, and operational efficiency justify a sustained premium to peers. The CommBank app (8.7M MAU), AI-driven personalisation, and industry-leading Net Promoter Score create a flywheel of customer acquisition, retention, and cross-sell that competitors cannot easily replicate. If CBA continues to gain market share while maintaining cost discipline, the premium multiple is defensible.

Each 25bp rate cut could reduce NIM by 2-4bp, with full pass-through on lending but sticky savings rates limiting deposit repricing. If NIM falls to 1.85-1.90%, EPS could decline 5-8% from peak levels.

identity.overview: Australia's largest bank by market capitalisation, serving ~17 million customers across retail, business, institutional, and wealth management. CBA holds #1 or #2 market share in home loans (~25%), household deposits (~27%), and business lending. The CommBank app is Australia's most-used banking app with 8.7M monthly active users. 1H FY25 cash NPAT was $5.13B (up 2%), NIM was 1.99% (down 4bp), and CET1 capital was 12.2%. RIO.heroDescription: Global Diversified Miner • ~57,000 Employees • CY2024: US$53.7B Revenue
RIO.heroCompanyDescription: Rio Tinto Limited (ASX: RIO) is the world's second-largest diversified mining company, operating across iron ore, aluminium, copper, minerals, and battery materials. The Pilbara iron ore system (~330Mtpa) generates ~65% of group EBITDA and is the world's lowest-cost major iron ore operation. Rio is undergoing a strategic pivot toward copper and lithium (Oyu Tolgoi ramp-up, Simandou development, Arcadium Lithium acquisition) to position for the energy transition. Dual-listed on ASX and LSE.

skew.rationale: Rio trades at ~10x forward earnings with a 5.4% dividend yield, reflecting market scepticism on China steel demand and iron ore prices. The iron ore franchise remains world-class (lowest quartile costs, ~$22/t C1), but the commodity price dependency creates binary risk. The Simandou project ($6.2B capex commitment) and Arcadium Lithium acquisition ($6.7B) add growth optionality but also execution risk. Balanced risk skew at current levels with upside if China stimulus materialises and downside if iron ore breaks below US$90/t.

verdict.text: CY2024 results delivered underlying earnings of US$11.8B (down 3%) on revenue of US$53.7B. The Pilbara iron ore system shipped 328Mt at C1 costs of US$21.7/t, maintaining world-leading margins. EBITDA margin was 39%. Net debt is a conservative US$5.5B (0.5x EBITDA). The dividend of US$3.41/share (60% payout) yields ~5.4%. However, the thesis is increasingly bifurcated: the iron ore cash machine is well-understood and fairly valued, while the growth portfolio (copper via Oyu Tolgoi, lithium via Arcadium, iron ore via Simandou) carries significant execution risk. At ~10x forward P/E, the market is pricing the cash flows but discounting the growth optionality.

RIO.featuredRationale: World-class iron ore franchise generates exceptional cash flow at current prices, but commodity dependency and China exposure create binary risk. Growth capex (Simandou, Arcadium) adds optionality but also execution uncertainty.

WOR.heroDescription: Global Engineering & Professional Services • ~35,000 Employees • FY24: $10.2B Revenue
WOR.heroCompanyDescription: Worley Limited (ASX: WOR) is a global engineering, procurement, construction, and consulting (EPC&C) company serving the energy, chemicals, and resources sectors. Formed from the 2019 merger of WorleyParsons and Jacobs ECR division, Worley now generates approximately 50% of revenue from sustainability-related projects (renewables, hydrogen, carbon capture, electrification) and 50% from traditional energy (LNG, upstream oil & gas, downstream refining). The company operates across 48 countries and is positioning itself as the engineering partner for the energy transition.

skew.rationale: Worley has de-rated 35% from its 2024 highs due to project delays, margin pressure from the Jacobs integration tail, and concerns about energy transition spending pace. At ~14.5x forward P/E with a $16.8B backlog and 50% sustainability revenue mix, the stock appears to price in a cyclical downturn that may not materialise. The energy transition capex cycle is multi-decade, and Worley's positioning across both traditional and sustainability engineering provides optionality. Risk skew tilts upside from these depressed levels.

verdict.text: FY24 (June year-end) delivered revenue of $10.2B (up 8%), underlying EBITA of $720M (up 12%), and a record backlog of $16.8B. The sustainability revenue mix reached 49% (vs 36% in FY22), confirming the structural shift. However, EBITA margin of 7.1% remains below the 8-9% target, dragged by legacy fixed-price contracts and integration costs. Net debt of $2.1B (2.9x EBITDA) is elevated but declining. The stock has sold off 35% on concerns about margin trajectory and project delays in hydrogen/CCS segments. At current levels, the market is pricing in execution failure rather than the structural growth opportunity the backlog implies.

WOR.featuredRationale: De-rated 35% from highs on margin concerns, but record backlog and 50% sustainability revenue mix underpin structural growth thesis. If margins recover to 8%+, significant re-rating potential from current levels.

If global energy transition capex accelerates to $4T+/year (IEA Net Zero pathway), Worley's backlog and revenue could grow 15-20% annually, driving a re-rating toward technology/infrastructure multiples.

hypotheses.title: Margin Pressure: Integration Drag and Fixed-Price Exposure
hypotheses.scoreMeta: Moderate conviction • Margin gap not closing
hypotheses.description: Worley's EBITA margin of 7.1% remains below the 8-9% target set at the time of the Jacobs acquisition (2019). The gap is driven by: (1) legacy fixed-price contracts inherited from Jacobs that are margin-dilutive, (2) sustainability projects averaging lower margins due to competitive pricing, (3) overhead from maintaining operations across 48 countries, and (4) $150M+ annual integration costs that have persisted longer than guided. If margins cannot reach 8%+ by FY26, the market will increasingly question management's execution credibility.

supporting: Margin miss: FY24 EBITA margin 7.1% vs 8-9% target. Margin has improved only 80bp in 3 years (from 6.3% in FY21), well below trajectory needed

Sustainability discount: Sustainability EBITA margin 6.5% vs traditional 8.0%. Competitive pressure in renewables engineering keeping margins low

contradicting: Fixed-price run-off: 80% of legacy fixed-price contracts will be completed by FY26. New contracts are predominantly cost-plus or reimbursable, reducing margin risk
Backlog quality: New backlog booked at average 8.2% EBITA margin, above current realised margin. As legacy contracts roll off, blended margin should converge upward
Cost programs: $200M cost reduction program underway (digital tools, shared services, office consolidation). Management guides $100M annualised savings by FY26

hypotheses.title: Cyclical Downturn: Energy Capex Correction
hypotheses.description: Worley is fundamentally an engineering services company exposed to energy capital expenditure cycles. In past downturns (2014-2016, 2020), revenue fell 20-30% and margins compressed to near-zero. If a global recession triggers simultaneous cuts in both traditional energy and sustainability capex, Worley's $16.8B backlog could deflate rapidly as clients defer or cancel projects. The elevated net debt (2.9x EBITDA) amplifies the downside.
requires: Global recession triggers oil price below US$50/bbl

Backlog cancellations exceed $2B in any 12-month period

supporting: Historical precedent: Revenue fell 28% in FY16 (oil downturn) and 15% in FY20 (COVID). EBITA margin hit 2.8% in FY20. Engineering services are inherently cyclical
Net Debt: $2.1B (2.9x EBITDA) provides limited buffer in a downturn. Covenant test at 3.5x. Refinancing risk if EBITA declines 20%+
Backlog vulnerability: $16.8B backlog includes pre-FID studies and early-stage FEED work that can be paused or cancelled without penalty
IRA uncertainty: $3B of sustainability backlog is linked to US IRA-subsidised projects. Policy reversal would trigger cancellations
contradicting: Diversification buffer: 50/50 traditional/sustainability mix provides natural hedge: if oil crashes, clean energy spending typically accelerates
Geographic spread: Revenue across 48 countries reduces single-market concentration. Middle East spending is counter-cyclical to Western markets
Sustaining capex base: ~40% of Worley's revenue is sustaining/maintenance work on existing facilities, which is more resilient than new-build capex

identity.overview: Global engineering and professional services company operating across energy, chemicals, and resources sectors. The 2019 acquisition of Jacobs ECR division ($4.6B) doubled Worley's scale and added North American and European exposure. Sustainability-related revenue has grown from 25% (FY20) to 49% (FY24), reflecting deliberate portfolio rotation toward renewables, hydrogen, carbon capture, and electrification projects. FY24 revenue $10.2B (+8%), underlying EBITA $720M (7.1% margin), backlog $16.8B (record). Net debt $2.1B declining from peak of $3.2B post-acquisition.
